column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=THE principles contained in Paper-bag Cookery are not new.
#Text=Woodsmen and
#Text= hunters have known for ages that if they wanted fish or game done to a
#Text= turn, a jacket of clay outside the meat which was protected from soil by
#Text= leaves or corn husks, gave, on removing the clay case, the very
#Text= quintessence of delicate, savory cookery.
#Text=Now within the last two years, a series of experiments has resulted in
#Text= the perfecting of a system of Paper-bag Cookery that revolutionizes the
#Text= old time kitchen drudgery with its unending round of greasy pots and
#Text= pans to be taken into account.
#Text=The advantages of this method of cooking are manifold.
#Text=They may be
#Text= epitomized thus:
#Text=
#Text= I.
#Text=It makes food more savory and nutritious.
#Text=II.
#Text=It is sanitary.
#Text=No dust can reach the article being cooked and, the
#Text= cooking accomplished, the bag can be thrown into the stove or kitchen
#Text= scrap basket with no temptation for a lazy maid to tuck away a greasy
#Text= pan in the dish closet for the delectation of "germs" or roaches.
#Text=III.
#Text=It is economical.
#Text=Not only does it save the time and strength of
#Text= the housewife with no aftermath of dirty cooking dishes to be washed,
#Text= but it prevents the shrinkage of meats as caused by ordinary cookery.
#Text=Nothing is lost, because there is no evaporation; careful experiments
#Text= prove that the weight of the cooked food tallies almost exactly with the
#Text= weight of the raw.
#Text=There is also a great saving of fuel, some claiming
#Text= as high as 40 per cent., owing to the less time required in Paper-bag
#Text= Cookery.
#Text=While this may be a generous estimate it is certain that
#Text= Paper-bag Cookery takes on the average, one-third less time than other
#Text= cooking.
#Text=IV.
#Text=With ordinary care there is no danger of food burning, and no
#Text= deterioration in flavor if left in the bag some little time before
#Text= serving.
#Text=V.
#Text=It is odorless; a great thing, this, for the flat-dweller who has to
#Text= cook in restricted quarters, taking care always that cooking odors do
#Text= not permeate the house.
#Text=VI.
#Text=Its price is not prohibitive.
#Text=Indeed, it is most reasonable.
#Text=Paper-bag Cookery calls for no big outlay of money, no patent stove
#Text= oven, no complex apparatus or appliances.
#Text=All that is necessary is an
#Text= oven of any sort--coal, gas, electric, wood or oil--a broiler, a paper
#Text= bag specially and sanitarily prepared,--grease proof and waterproof,--a
#Text= wood cookery dish if the food contains liquid or a number of separate
#Text= ingredients, and something to cook therein.
#Text=Another convenience are the
#Text= wire clips for fastening the mouth and corners of the bag, which can be
#Text= purchased wherever the bags are sold.
#Text=THE KIND OF PAPER BAG TO USE.
#Text=While a sheet of heavy foolscap paper made into a bag serves for the
#Text= cooking of a single chop--it is self-evident that for larger
#Text= proportions, larger bags and bags from strong, absolutely sanitary paper
#Text= must be used.
#Text=While there are bags and bags now upon the market, not all
#Text= fulfill these essential conditions.
#Text=After much experimenting, the
#Text= Continental Paper Bag Co., of Rumford, Maine, and New York City, has
#Text=succeeded in producing the ideal bag which may now be found in varying
#Text= sizes, at all the large house-furnishing stores, grocers, butchers,
#Text= etc., or the bags may be ordered direct from headquarters.
#Text=These bags
#Text= are put up in bulk in bundle lots, or in sealed packages of assorted
#Text= sizes.
#Text=Each of the sealed packages contains thirty bags of assorted
#Text= sizes with the necessary clips and a small book of recipes with full
#Text= directions.
#Text=Retail price 25 cents a package--fifty packages to a
#Text= shipping bundle.
#Text=In order to make paper bag cookery of the greatest value to housewives,
#Text= both as regards cleanliness and ease of operation, to say nothing of the
#Text= many cases where the flavor of the food is actually improved, the author
#Text= heartily recommends the use of specially prepared wood cookery dishes.
#Text=These dishes are most inexpensive, varying in price from about thirty
#Text= for ten cents to six for ten cents, depending upon size.
#Text=They can be
#Text= purchased wherever the paper bags are sold,--department stores, house
#Text= furnishing stores, grocery stores, etc., etc., or may be obtained direct
#Text= from the Oval Wood Dish Company, Delta, Ohio.
#Text=The food is placed in the
#Text= wood cookery dish and the dish is put into the bag.
#Text=The advantage lies
#Text= in the fact that should the bag break, the food and juices are saved in
#Text=cooking, light for five minutes before the bag goes into the oven.
#Text=The
#Text= average oven heat should be not less than 200 degrees Fahrenheit, and
#Text= may be 250 degrees.
#Text=When the bag is put into the oven, the heat must be
#Text= at once reduced to 170 degrees.
#Text=An inexperienced cook lacking an oven
#Text= thermometer can test the right degree of heat by placing a bit of paper
#Text= in the oven and noting the color it assumes.
#Text=At the end of five minutes
#Text= it should be a light golden brown.
#Text=If the heat is too intense the bag will burst.
#Text=Now carefully lay the bag
#Text= on the grid shelves or wire broilers--never on solid shelves, being
#Text= careful to _place the seam side of the bag up_.
#Text=This is imperative, as otherwise the juices of the food being cooked may
#Text= cause the seam to open, and distribute its contents over the oven.
#Text=Once
#Text= placed in position, roasts and entrees on the lower shelf, about an inch
#Text= from the oven floor, fish on the middle shelf, and pastry on the top
#Text= where heat is most intense,--do not move or open the bags until the
#Text= schedule time of their cooking is accomplished.
#Text=In placing the article
#Text= to be cooked, take care that the bag does not touch the sides of the
#Text= oven and that it is not too close to the flames.
#Text=When the time limit of
#Text=cooking has expired, take up the bag from the shelf by drawing _with_
#Text= the wires, not across them, which is apt to tear the bag made tender by
#Text= charring.
#Text=Slip on to the lid of a pot or flat tin held just beneath the
#Text= grid and thence to the heated platter.
#Text=To secure the gravy, stick a
#Text= pinhole in the bottom of the bag and allow it to drain on to the
#Text= platter, or serving dish.
#Text=Rip open the bag from the top and throw the
#Text= charred fragments away at once.
#Text=If to be served hot, arrange at once on
#Text= a heated platter or other dish, with its appropriate garnish.
#Text=POINTERS FOR PAPER BAG COOKERY.
#Text=I.
#Text=In the case of a coal-heated oven with solid shelves a wire broiler
#Text= or "grid" should be substituted as the heat must be allowed to circulate
#Text= on all sides of the bag.
#Text=II.
#Text=The size of the oven makes no difference but it _must be kept
#Text= clean_.
#Text=III.
#Text=In the case of a fowl or joint see that there are no rough edges or
#Text=bones protruding that will be likely to pierce the bag.
#Text=IV.
#Text=Do not season the article to be cooked too highly as none of the
#Text= seasonings are dissipated during the cooking as is usually the case in
#Text= ordinary boiling or roasting.
#Text=V.
#Text=For cooking fruit, grease the outside of the bag.
#Text=VI.
#Text=In removing the bag from the oven, draw with the wires, not across
#Text= them.
#Text=VII.
#Text=To brown things at the last of the cooking, if necessary, puncture
#Text= a few holes in the top of the bag.
#Text=VIII.
#Text=If a bag breaks in the cooking, as it sometimes will if the heat
#Text= is too intense, do not try to remove the article being cooked from the
#Text= bag, but slip the whole into a new well-greased bag.
#Text=The use of two bags
#Text= is better than one when things require long cooking or for meats with
#Text= much fat or juicy dishes.
#Text=While it may cost a bit more, it will save
#Text= much anxiety lest the bag burst.
#Text=IX.
#Text=To avoid having any chance drippings soil the oven floor, slip a
#Text= thin tin baking sheet or shallow dripper under the broiler, letting it
#Text= rest flat on the bottom of the oven.
#Text=Put in a little hot water and this
#Text= steam will keep the bag moist and do much to discourage its breaking.
#Text=Indeed, in baking any kind of fruit cake, which requires slow cooking,
#Text= quite a little water in the drip-pan underneath is advisable.
#Text=X.
#Text=In baking pastry and cake, a few tiny holes should be made in the
#Text= upper side of the bag before putting in the oven.
#Text=This will brown the
#Text= surface of the cake delicately.
#Text=XI.
#Text=Do not let the bag touch the sides of the oven or the gas flames.
#Text=XII.
#Text=Wire trivets such as are sold at house-furnishing stores for use in
#Text= cooling bread and cakes will be found a great convenience.
#Text=If a bag is
#Text= laid on a trivet, it can then be easily set in the oven and as easily
#Text= lifted out when done.
#Text=XIII.
#Text=Never try to take things from the oven with the gas lighted.
#Text=FISH and the paper bag method of cooking, go hand and glove.
#Text=The thing
#Text= that every housewife hates most, particularly in a small apartment, or
#Text= in the Winter when it is difficult to get the house thoroughly aired, is
#Text= the pervasive odor that announces to every one in the house or block
#Text= just what you are going to have for dinner.
#Text=Bagged, the odor is so
#Text= minimized as to be entirely inoffensive.
#Text=Ten minutes airing after the
#Text= bag is opened will be quite sufficient to dissipate every particle of
#Text= odor.
#Text=Furthermore, the fish itself is much more delicate and digestible
#Text= with all the flavor of fish and seasoning held in and united in a
#Text= harmonious whole.
#Text=Of course, this presupposes a fresh fish to start
#Text= with, or one just out of cold storage, before it has had a chance to
#Text= thaw and develope ptomaines.
#Text=In buying fish, look at the eyes and flesh.
#Text=Fish should be firm to the touch.
#Text=If pressed by the finger the flesh
#Text= should rise instantly.
#Text=There should be no impression left.
#Text=If fish is
#Text= fresh the eyes are bright and the gills red and the scales not easily
#Text= rubbed off.
#Text=Never lay fish directly on artificial ice, say the
#Text= fishermen, as the ammonia used in the freezing affects them injuriously.
#Text=Shell fish are not so apt to spoil as the other fish.
#Text=The wood cookery dishes will be found of great value in cooking all
#Text= kinds of fish in paper bags.
#Text=In many cases the flavor of the fish is
#Text= improved and the fish can always be taken from the bag with ease and
#Text= served whole if desired.
#Text==Clam Pies.
#Text==--Line little tins or moulds with paste and put in a layer
#Text= of raw clams with a seasoning of butter and pepper.
#Text=Dredge with flour,
#Text= add a spoonful or two of clam juice, cover with the paste, cut a hole in
#Text= the top, brush with beaten egg, slip into the bag, fasten and bake
#Text= twenty minutes.
#Text==Roast Clams.
#Text==--Scrub the shells clean and slip in the bag.
#Text=As soon as
#Text= the shells open, remove carefully and pour off the extra liquor in as
#Text= many small cups as you have persons to serve.
#Text=Put a cup of the juice to
#Text= which a bit of butter and dusting of pepper has been added, in the
#Text= center of a soup dish, and arrange the clams around it.
#Text=With an oyster
#Text= fork, the clams may then be removed from the shell, dipped into the
#Text= liquor and eaten.
#Text=Serve very hot with quarters of lemon.
#Text==Crabs, Soft and Hard.
#Text==--While soft shell crabs are too expensive for
#Text= the purse of moderate depth, the hard shell crustacean is always in
#Text= order and greatly to be desired.
#Text=Crabs, like all other shell fish, are
#Text= best when fresh from their native waters, and the individual who can do
#Text= his own crabbing and then eat the fruits of his labor with the flavor of
#Text= the sea still with them, has nothing more to be desired from a
#Text= gastronomic standpoint.
#Text=In most markets crabs may be found both alive
#Text= and boiled.
#Text=If alive, keep them in cold water until ready to cook.
#Text=If
#Text= already boiled, use them as soon as possible as they do not keep well
#Text= for more than twenty-four hours.
#Text=When ready to cook live crabs, take up
#Text= on a skimmer, handling gingerly so as to avoid a pinch, and drop into a
#Text= large kettle of boiling salted water.
#Text=Cook gently fifteen minutes, or
#Text= until a bright red, skim out, and cool, twist off the claws, remove the
#Text= upper shell from the under, scrape the spongy portions from the sides,
#Text= remove the green portion and wash free from sand.
#Text=Crack the large claws
#Text= and remove the meat.
#Text=If you are to serve the crab meat in the shells,
#Text= wash and dry as many of the upper ones as desired.
#Text=These preliminaries
#Text= attended to, the crabs are ready to use, in any one of a dozen different
#Text= ways.
#Text=night supper these chops may be cooked early in the day, then simply
#Text= re-bagged and heated in the oven for the meal.
#Text==Coquilles of Lobster.
#Text==--Cook two tablespoonfuls of finely chopped onion
#Text= in a tablespoonful butter for fifteen minutes.
#Text=Have ready a cream sauce
#Text= made by melting together over the fire a tablespoonful each of butter
#Text= and flour, then thinning with a cupful of white stock that has been
#Text= cooked with a small bouquet of sweet herbs.
#Text=Salt and pepper to taste,
#Text= and if you like add half a cupful chopped mushrooms and their liquor.
#Text=Add to the lightly browned onions two cupfuls finely cut lobster meat, a
#Text= tablespoonful minced parsley, one cupful of the made sauce and salt and
#Text= paprika.
#Text=Cook together ten minutes, then put the mixture into the
#Text= shells, pour a little of the sauce over each, sprinkle with buttered
#Text= bread crumbs, bag, and bake about ten minutes or until they are browned.
#Text==Lobster in Shells.
#Text==--Cut the meat from two cans of lobster into small
#Text= pieces.
#Text=Sprinkle a few bread crumbs and a little salt and pepper over
#Text= it.
#Text=Then put in shells.
#Text=On each shell put a good sized lump of butter,
#Text= two teaspoonfuls of wine, some more salt and pepper and some more bread
#Text= crumbs.
#Text=Put prepared shells in a paper bag, put in a hot oven and cook
#Text=ten minutes.
#Text==Mussels au Gratin.
#Text==--Remove and clean the mussels, straining all the
#Text= liquor thoroughly.
#Text=Then make this sauce: Fry two tablespoonfuls of
#Text= chopped onions in butter for a few minutes, but do not let them brown;
#Text= add about a teaspoonful of flour, and, while the onions are blending,
#Text= add the liquor of the mussels, stirring it in slowly.
#Text=Cook this mixture
#Text= for a few minutes; then add a tablespoonful of vinegar, the same
#Text= quantity of chopped parsley and pepper and salt to taste.
#Text=Butter a
#Text= shallow earthen or wooden baking dish; in the bottom spread a layer of
#Text= the sauce, lay the mussels on top of it and cover them with the balance
#Text= of the sauce.
#Text=Over all this spread a thin coating of breadcrumbs; butter
#Text= and bake in bag until they have browned.
#Text=Serve in the same dish in which
#Text= they were baked.
#Text==Boxed Oysters (Virginia Style).
#Text==--Take crusty rolls, cut off the top
#Text= and scoop out the hearts leaving them each like a box.
#Text=Fill the space
#Text= with oysters, seasoning with salt, pepper and butter and sprinkling over
#Text= them some of the crumb of the roll that you have removed.
#Text=Put bits of
#Text= butter on top, then replace the cover.
#Text=Set the rolls in the buttered bag
#Text=and pour the strained oyster liquor over them.
#Text=Put into a hot oven and
#Text= bake for fifteen minutes.
#Text=Serve hot.
#Text=Lemon juice or a little mace is
#Text= sometimes used for seasoning the oysters.
#Text==Spindled Oysters and Bacon.
#Text==--For two dozen large oysters have two
#Text= dozen thin slices bacon, and a half dozen slices crisp toast.
#Text=Have ready
#Text= a half dozen slender steel skewers.
#Text=Fill these skewers with alternate
#Text= slices of bacon and oysters, running the skewer crosswise through the
#Text= eye of the oyster and threading the bacon by one corner, so that each
#Text= slice blankets an oyster.
#Text=Do not crowd.
#Text=Lay the skewers in a buttered
#Text= bag, and cook in a quick oven ten minutes.
#Text=Lay each spindle with its
#Text= contents undisturbed on a slice of toast, pour the drip from the bag
#Text= over them and serve at once.
#Text=CHAPTER VII.
#Text=FISH.
#Text=fish to them.
#Text=Pour all into bag, seal and bake twenty minutes in a
#Text= moderate oven, half an hour.
#Text==Planked Fish Bag-Cooked.
#Text==--Planked fish responds beautifully to the
#Text= paper-bag treatment, and there is no better way of developing the
#Text= distinctive flavor of any of the delicate white-meated fish.
#Text=The plank
#Text= however should not be as thick as that usually required.
#Text=It must be of
#Text= hard-wood, hickory, cherry, live oak, cedar or ash--well seasoned and
#Text= sawed about a half inch in thickness, rounded and tapered at one end
#Text= like an ironing board.
#Text=This to accommodate the tail of the fish.
#Text=If
#Text= cooking small fish use the oval wood cooking dishes made of maple wood.
#Text=Make it very hot in the oven or under the gas flame, then grease well
#Text= with vegetable oil, olive or the refined cotton seed, and lay on it the
#Text= fish cleaned, split down the back, seasoned, oiled all over with the
#Text= sweetest of vegetable oils or butter and spread out as flat as possible
#Text= with the skin side next to the hot board.
#Text=Slip into the greased bag and
#Text= fasten tightly.
#Text=If you use the gas oven for planking your fish, as most
#Text= of us do, turn on both burners until the oven is very hot.
#Text=Then set in
#Text= the fish with a trivet under the bag the same as if you were cooking
#Text=everywhere as in the brown part.
#Text=Cook the liver, gizzard and neck in a
#Text= small separate bag, wrapping each in a slice of bacon and seasoning
#Text= them with salt and pepper.
#Text=Add a very little water, seal and put on to
#Text= cook less than an hour before dinner time.
#Text=The slow heat will make them
#Text= very tender.
#Text=Cooked with capon, they would be overdone.
#Text=Serve with sweet
#Text= potatoes Southern style, or baked apples slightly sweetened.
#Text==Chicken with Parsnips.
#Text==--Wash, parboil and scrape a quart of tender
#Text= parsnips.
#Text=Split a Spring chicken down the back and lay in a buttered
#Text= bag, skin side up.
#Text=Arrange the sliced parsnips around the chicken,
#Text= sprinkle with salt and pepper, dot with bits of butter until a half cup
#Text= has been used, and top with two or three thin slices of fat, salt pork.
#Text=Put a half cup hot water in the bag and bake to a delicate brown.
#Text=Put
#Text= the chicken on a hot platter and arrange the parsnips around it.
#Text=Make a
#Text= cream gravy from the drippings in the bag and serve with mashed
#Text= potatoes, currant jelly and beet greens.
#Text==Chicken à la Baltimore.
#Text==--Take two small Spring chickens, prepare as
#Text= for broiling, but cut into joints.
#Text=Wipe dry, season well with salt and
#Text= pepper, dip into beaten egg, then cover well with bread crumbs.
#Text=Place in
#Text=a well-buttered bag, pour a little melted butter or oil over them and
#Text= bake in the oven twenty or twenty-five minutes.
#Text=Serve with cream sauce
#Text= and garnish with thin, crisped slices of bacon and tiny corn oysters.
#Text==Chicken Croquettes.
#Text==--This may be made from left-over cooked chicken or
#Text= from canned chicken.
#Text=For a dozen croquettes allow one cupful of solid
#Text= meat chopped fine, a cupful of cream sauce, made by cooking together
#Text= four tablespoonfuls of butter and two of flour, then stirring in a scant
#Text= cupful of hot milk and cooking until smooth and thick.
#Text=Combine chicken
#Text= and sauce, season with half a teaspoonful each plain and celery salt, a
#Text= teaspoonful of onion juice, a little lemon juice and chopped parsley.
#Text=Mix thoroughly, then set the mixture away to cool.
#Text=When cool and stiff
#Text= roll in finely powdered bread crumbs so that every bit of the chicken is
#Text= covered and shape into cones, cutlets or cylinders.
#Text=Have ready a beaten
#Text= egg to which a scant tablespoonful of milk has been added, dip the
#Text= croquettes in this, drain well, roll in crumbs again, and again set
#Text= aside to cool and stiffen.
#Text=When ready to cook, slip in well-buttered bag
#Text= and bake in a hot oven twenty minutes.
#Text==Paper Bagged Chicken.
#Text==--Split the chicken down the middle of the back,
#Text=spread flat, and put a skewer in each side to prevent it from curling.
#Text=Beat up a very fresh egg, with a pinch of salt, black pepper to taste,
#Text= an ounce of melted butter, a teaspoonful of Worcestershire sauce or
#Text= something similar and a teaspoonful of made mustard.
#Text=Mix well.
#Text=With a
#Text= brush glaze the chicken with the mixture.
#Text=Place in a greased bag with
#Text= bread crumbs around and over it.
#Text=Be careful that the skewers do not tear
#Text= the bag.
#Text=Seal up tight and cook from thirty-five to forty minutes in a
#Text= very hot oven.
#Text==Chicken Pie.
#Text==--Disjoint two chickens and cook until tender in just
#Text= enough water to cover.
#Text=Remove all the thick skin and the largest bones.
#Text=Line a baking dish with good paste, pack the chicken in layers and dust
#Text= each with salt, pepper and flour.
#Text=Pour in enough of the chicken liquor
#Text= to come nearly to the top; lay on a tablespoon of butter and cover with
#Text= a crust after cutting out a piece as large as the top of a small cup.
#Text=Moisten the edges and press together, then ornament the top with leaves
#Text= cut from the trimmings of paste.
#Text=Bag and bake in a quick oven.
#Text==Paste for Chicken Pie.
#Text==--Sift five level teaspoons of baking powder and
#Text= one level teaspoon of salt with four cups of flour and rub in one cup of
#Text=closely packed Hamburg steak is bound to be tough and dry.
#Text=Better add a
#Text= beaten egg to hold the chopped meat together than press the small and
#Text= delicate particles of meat compactly.
#Text=Season lightly, brush over with oil or melted butter and lay in buttered
#Text= bag.
#Text=Seal and roast for half an hour.
#Text=Take up on a hot platter, season,
#Text= add a little melted butter mixed with finely chopped parsley and serve
#Text= hot with baked or mashed potatoes.
#Text=A tomato sauce may go with the steaks
#Text= or a brown gravy made from beef stock.
#Text=A pleasant change in the
#Text= appearance of Hamburg steak can be effected by shaping it to look like
#Text= lamb chops.
#Text=When these are bag broiled with a bit of macaroni in each
#Text= end to simulate the chop bone they can be arranged to stand on a bed of
#Text= parsley stacked against a pretty bowl containing tomato sauce or stewed
#Text= tomato, a spoonful of which is to be served with each portion.
#Text=The bed
#Text= on which the chops are to rest may be mashed potato or peas, if
#Text= preferred to the parsley.
#Text==Pot Roast.
#Text==--While this does not eliminate washing the pot, the juices
#Text= and flavor of the beef are so conserved that instead of the usual dry
#Text= pot-roast it is moist and tender and so well worth the trouble.
#Text=Peel and slice a good sized onion and brown in a round bottomed iron pot
#Text= with a piece of beef suet.
#Text=Wash a four or five pound piece of bottom
#Text= round, place in the pot without any water and brown quickly on all
#Text= sides, turning it without piercing with a fork.
#Text=When very brown add a
#Text= small cup of water, push it back and let simmer for one hour, turning
#Text= frequently.
#Text=Season and cook for ten minutes longer, then place it in a
#Text= well-greased bag, seal and put in a hot oven on a broiler, adding about
#Text= a cupful of the liquid in which it was cooking, before sealing.
#Text=Reduce
#Text= the heat of the oven after ten minutes and cook an hour and a half to
#Text= two hours according to size.
#Text=Potatoes may be peeled and browned in the
#Text= gravy left in the pot.
#Text=When done, the liquid in the bag should be added
#Text= to that in the pot and thickened for gravy, first skimming off the fat
#Text= if too rich.
#Text==Rib Roast of Beef.
#Text==--Grease the roast lightly with drippings or
#Text= vegetable oil, season with pepper, but not with salt, dust lightly with
#Text= flour and place in well-greased bag, seal, and place in a hot oven, at
#Text= the end of fifteen minutes, reduce the heat one-half and continue
#Text= cooking for half an hour longer in case of a three pound roast or for a
#Text=cloth.
#Text=Divide in nice pieces, dip in a batter made of one egg, one
#Text= tablespoonful of milk, salt and pepper to season and flour to make of
#Text= the consistency of cream.
#Text=Arrange these pieces in a buttered bag.
#Text=Seal
#Text= and bake ten minutes.
#Text=Serve with fried parsley.
#Text==Lamb  '  s Kidney.
#Text==--Skin, split, dip in butter and place on skewer.
#Text=Dust
#Text= with salt and pepper, and place in buttered bag.
#Text=Seal, place in hot oven
#Text= and cook eight minutes.
#Text==Leg of Mutton Cooked in Cider.
#Text==--Buy the leg of mutton two or three
#Text= days before you wish to serve it.
#Text=Take off the "woolly" skin that has
#Text= the strong taste on the outside and wipe carefully with a damp cloth.
#Text=Then rub with a mixture of spices, using half a teaspoonful each of
#Text= cinnamon, cloves, allspice, pepper and nutmeg.
#Text=Rub thoroughly and hang
#Text= the mutton in a cool place for two days; then put in a well-greased bag,
#Text= adding four onions chopped fine, a cupful seedless raisins and a cupful
#Text= of sweet cider.
#Text=Put in hot oven and bake half an hour, then reduce the
#Text= heat, and cook an hour and a half.
#Text=Serve with a hot cider sauce.
#Text==Mutton Chops and Sausage.
#Text==--Place two thick chops in a wooden dish with
#Text=three links of sausage.
#Text=Season lightly with salt and pepper, lay two
#Text= strips of bacon over the top of the chops and seal in bag.
#Text=Bake from
#Text= twenty minutes to half an hour in a moderate oven.
#Text==Ragout of Lamb.
#Text==--Grease the bag well, and lay in a layer of sliced raw
#Text= potatoes, seasoned lightly.
#Text=Put on top of the potatoes a layer of meat,
#Text= seasoned with salt, pepper and chopped parsley, and lay thin slices of
#Text= onion across meat.
#Text=Add one-half cup canned tomato or tomato sauce, cover
#Text= the whole with another layer of sliced potato, seal, and bake
#Text= thirty-five minutes.
#Text=You may use a wooden cooking dish here to
#Text= advantage.
#Text==Roast Leg of Lamb.
#Text==--Trim nicely and rub over with oil, dredge with a
#Text= little flour and season with salt, pepper and powdered mint.
#Text=Seal and
#Text= bake two hours.
#Text=Serve with mint sauce.
#Text==A Genuine Irish Stew.
#Text==--Cut two pounds of chops from the best end of a
#Text= neck of mutton, and pare away nearly all the fat.
#Text=A portion of the
#Text= breast may be cut into squares and used, but a neck of mutton is the
#Text= best joint for the purpose.
#Text=Take as many potatoes as will amount after
#Text=peeling to twice the weight of the meat.
#Text=Slice them with eight large
#Text= onions sliced.
#Text=Put a layer of mixed potatoes and onions at the bottom of
#Text= the buttered paper bag.
#Text=Place the meat on this and season it plentifully
#Text= with pepper and lightly with salt.
#Text=Pack closely, and cover the meat with
#Text= another layer of potato and onion.
#Text=Pour in as much water or stock as
#Text= will moisten the topmost layer, seal tightly, and let the contents cook
#Text= gently for two and a half hours.
#Text=You may use one of the large wooden
#Text= cooking dishes here.
#Text=CHAPTER XII.
#Text=PORK IN VARIED FORMS.
#Text==Bacon and Apples.
#Text==--CORE, but do not peel, well flavored apples and cut
#Text= in crosswise rings about a quarter of an inch thick.
#Text=Lay on thin slices
#Text= of streaky bacon in a well-buttered bag, dust lightly with sugar, seal
#Text=and cook eight minutes in a hot oven.
#Text==Bacon and Bananas.
#Text==--Peel firm bananas, halve them lengthwise, dust
#Text= lightly with pepper and wrap each in a thin slice of streaky bacon.
#Text=Put
#Text= in a well-greased bag, seal and cook in a hot oven ten minutes.
#Text==Bacon and Calf  '  s Liver.
#Text==--Pour boiling water over thin slices of calf  '  s
#Text= liver and let stand ten minutes.
#Text=Drain, pat dry and dredge with flour,
#Text= seasoning with pepper and a little salt.
#Text=Lay slices of bacon in a
#Text= greased bag and on top put a layer of the liver, seal and bake fifteen
#Text= minutes.
#Text=Serve on hot platter.
#Text==Baked Pork Chops.
#Text==--Season with salt and pepper, then cover each side
#Text= of the chops with a forcemeat made moist enough to stick to them.
#Text=Place
#Text= in a well-greased bag, adding a spoonful of water, seal and bake
#Text= twenty-five minutes.
#Text==Pork Chops and Sweet Potatoes.
#Text==--Select six sweet potatoes of uniform
#Text= size.
#Text=Peel, cut in half lengthwise, brush each piece all over with
#Text= melted butter and dredge lightly with powdered sugar.
#Text=Place in a
#Text=thoroughly buttered bag flat side down.
#Text=On top of them put pork chops,
#Text= seasoned, rolled in flour and from which the fat has been partly
#Text= trimmed.
#Text=Seal and bake in hot oven on broiler for twenty-five minutes.
#Text=Pork chops cooked in this way are as tender as chicken, not hard in
#Text= fibre as they usually are when fried.
#Text==Ham and Scalloped Potatoes.
#Text==--Peel and slice potatoes very thin.
#Text=Put a
#Text= layer in the bottom of a buttered bag and on top of the potatoes a layer
#Text= of raw ham sliced very thin, and with the most of the fat trimmed off.
#Text=Sprinkle with a little flour.
#Text=Add little bits of butter rolled in flour
#Text= and salt and pepper to season.
#Text=Proceed in this way until the desired
#Text= amount is obtained, having the top layer of potatoes sprinkled with
#Text= flour and bits of butter.
#Text=Turn in enough sweet milk or cream to come
#Text= even with the top layer, and bake twenty minutes or until the potatoes
#Text= are tender.
#Text=The trimmings from the fat of the ham can be used in place
#Text= of the butter if preferred.
#Text=One of the wooden cooking dishes is
#Text= convenient here.
#Text==Ham, Spinach and Lamb Chops.
#Text==--Place two or more slices of ham in a
#Text=
#Text= =Spanish Sauce.
#Text==--For veal, lamb or mutton chops, broiled or fried fish,
#Text= chicken, etc.
#Text=One large onion, one full section of garlic, one-half
#Text= large sweet, green or red pepper.
#Text=Put in two tablespoonfuls of butter,
#Text= one teaspoonful of olive or vegetable oil.
#Text=When effervescing stops add a
#Text= half teaspoonful of salt, and the onion, garlic and green pepper which
#Text= has been finely grated.
#Text=When this begins to brown, giving it time to
#Text= cook rather well, add four good sized tomatoes, skinned and chopped, or
#Text= the thick part of one can of tomatoes.
#Text=Let all simmer for fifteen to
#Text= twenty minutes with occasional stirring to prevent burning.
#Text=Add salt and
#Text= pepper, paprika, or cayenne to taste, two tablespoonfuls tomato ketchup
#Text= and one dessertspoonful Worcestershire Sauce, before taking off fire.
#Text=It should be the consistency of good cream.
#Text=If too thin, cook down, or
#Text= if too thick add a sufficient amount of _boiling_ water.
#Text=Use red pepper
#Text= as a seasoning.
#Text==Thick Tomato Sauce.
#Text==--Blend over the fire two tablespoonfuls of melted
#Text= butter and two tablespoonfuls of flour; add a little at a time, and
#Text= stirring all the while, one large cupful of tomato juice.
#Text=Stir until the
#Text= mixture thickens; then season to taste with sugar, salt and cayenne
#Text=pepper.
#Text=The seasoning may sometimes be varied by adding a little chopped
#Text= parsley or chopped onion or even both.
#Text=For a thinner tomato sauce--use
#Text= but one tablespoonful of butter and one of flour to each cupful of
#Text= liquor.
#Text==Sauce Tartare.
#Text==--Make first a good mayonnaise, then finish with the
#Text= addition of a tablespoonful each of chopped gherkins, olives, parsley
#Text= and capers; mix together in a bowl a half teaspoonful of salt, a half
#Text= teaspoonful mustard, a half teaspoonful of powdered sugar and a half
#Text= saltspoonful of pepper; add the yolks of two raw eggs that have been in
#Text= the ice box long enough to be as cold as possible and beat lightly;
#Text= measure out a half cupful of olive oil and have this cold also; add the
#Text= oil slowly at first, then as it begins to thicken it can be poured in
#Text= more rapidly.
#Text=When quite thick, add three tablespoonfuls of vinegar,
#Text= then the chopped ingredients.
#Text=This will keep several weeks.
#Text=Tarragon
#Text= vinegar may be used in place of the cider vinegar if preferred.
#Text=cooked until smooth and thick.
#Text=Season with salt and pepper and add
#Text= enough to the chicken to make stiff enough to handle when cold.
#Text=When
#Text= cold shape into balls, roll in fine, dry bread crumbs and beaten egg
#Text= diluted with a little water, then crumb again and place in well-greased
#Text= bag.
#Text=Seal and cook ten minutes.
#Text==Mock Fried Oysters.
#Text==--To two cupfuls cold boiled rice, add one tin of
#Text= sardines, from which all bone and skin have been removed.
#Text=Roll this
#Text= coarse paste into flat, circular cakes, put into well-greased bag and
#Text= bake fifteen minutes in moderate oven.
#Text==Turkey Croquettes.
#Text==--Chop the fragments of turkey or other left over
#Text= meats very fine, adding for seasoning a small portion of bologna, ham or
#Text= tongue together with a bit of fine minced onion or onion juice, salt,
#Text= pepper and parsley.
#Text=Make a thick cream sauce, allowing for a pint of the
#Text= chopped and seasoned meat the following portions:
#Text=
#Text= Put into a saucepan a heaping tablespoonful butter and two level
#Text= tablespoonfuls of flour.
#Text=As soon as blended, pour in a cupful of hot
#Text= milk stirring until thick and smooth.
#Text=Salt to taste.
#Text=Add the meat and
#Text=beat until well mixed.
#Text=Season more highly if desired, then set away in a cold place until cold
#Text= and stiffened.
#Text=Form into cones.
#Text=Dip in beaten egg, roll in fine crumbs
#Text= and place in a cold place again until quite dry.
#Text=Bake in well-greased
#Text= bag and stick a little sprig of parsley in the end of each cone before
#Text= serving.
#Text==Edinboro Hot Pot.
#Text==--You will need for this one pound of cold meat
#Text= sliced and browned in sweet drippings, one large onion sliced and
#Text= browned in the same drippings, a half tin of tomatoes, a half dozen cold
#Text= boiled or baked potatoes sliced and a little good stock made from the
#Text= bones and seasoning.
#Text=Put a layer of meat in the well-greased bag or in
#Text= one of the oval wood cookery dishes made specially for the purpose.
#Text=On
#Text= top of the meat put some of the onions, tomatoes and potatoes.
#Text=Season
#Text= with salt, pepper and butter or vegetable shortening and pour over all
#Text= about a cupful of good stock.
#Text=Seal the bag and bake for a half hour in
#Text= a moderate oven.
#Text==Individual Meat Pies.
#Text==--Chop fine any cold cooked meat.
#Text=Season highly
#Text=with mustard, pepper sauce and catsup, salt and pepper; add one egg;
#Text= moisten with liquor of oysters.
#Text=Make a rich biscuit crust, roll out to a
#Text= quarter of an inch thickness, and cut in squares.
#Text=Fill half of each
#Text= square with one tablespoonful of the prepared meat.
#Text=Fold remaining half
#Text= of square over, first moistening edges with oyster liquor, and press
#Text= closely together.
#Text=Put in buttered bag and bake twenty minutes in hot
#Text= oven, reducing the heat after the first ten minutes.
#Text==English Pasties.
#Text==--Cut any cold meat up into small pieces, add a cupful
#Text= of sliced potatoes, raw, and an onion chopped fine, some parsley and
#Text= pepper and salt to taste.
#Text=Stew this until the potato is done and thicken
#Text= with flour rubbed in butter.
#Text=Make a crust of flour and salt, using
#Text= chopped suet and butter in equal quantities for shortening and a
#Text= teaspoonful of baking powder to each quart of flour.
#Text=Roll the crust out
#Text= thin and cut into large discs--the cover of a two quart pail makes a
#Text= good pastie cutter.
#Text=Put two large spoonfuls of the meat mixture on the
#Text= crust and roll over, pinching edges together like a fruit turnover.
#Text=Bag
#Text= and bake one-half hour in a hot oven.
#Text=If there is any of the meat gravy
#Text= left serve it with the pasties.
#Text=VEGETABLES.
#Text=WHILE no claim is made that all vegetables are improved through paper
#Text= bag cookery, experiments prove that quite a number can be successfully
#Text= cooked by the paper bag process.
#Text=Vegetables of strong flavor as a rule
#Text= are best cooked in a large quantity of water and are not recommended for
#Text= paper bag cookery; only the more delicate vegetables that need to have
#Text= their flavors conserved.
#Text=Dried peas, lentils and beans are excellent
#Text= cooked in paper bags but require a longer preliminary soaking than is
#Text= usual with other methods of cooking.
#Text==Asparagus.
#Text==--Trim and scrape as for boiling; wash very clean.
#Text=Tie in
#Text= bundles and put into a buttered bag with a little salt and a quarter
#Text= cupful of water.
#Text=Seal and cook from thirty-five to forty minutes in a
#Text= hot oven.
#Text==Asparagus With Cheese.
#Text==--Boil two bunches of asparagus twelve minutes
#Text= in salted water.
#Text=Drain, but save the water.
#Text=Put the asparagus in a
#Text=buttered bag or in one of the oval wooden dishes, scattering grated
#Text= Swiss or Parmesan cheese between the layers.
#Text=Turn over all a cup of the
#Text= water in which the asparagus was boiled, sprinkle the top of the scallop
#Text= with a little cheese and a few buttered bread crumbs.
#Text=Seal the bag and
#Text= cook fifteen minutes in a moderate oven.
#Text==Lima Beans.
#Text==--Add to a quart of shelled Lima beans three tablespoonfuls
#Text= of butter or vegetable oil, a quarter pound of diced bacon or ham, a
#Text= little minced parsley or other seasoning herbs, and a teaspoonful of
#Text= flour.
#Text=Put in a greased bag with a cupful of water, seal and cook an
#Text= hour in a moderate oven.
#Text==String Beans, Oriental Style.
#Text==--String the beans, cut in two
#Text= lengthwise, then break in inch pieces.
#Text=To every pint of beans, which
#Text= should be young and tender, allow one cupful boiling water, two
#Text= tablespoonfuls vegetable oil, one small onion sliced, and a half cupful
#Text= tomato.
#Text=Salt and pepper to taste.
#Text=Put all in greased paper bag and cook
#Text= forty-five minutes.
#Text=A wooden cookery dish can be employed to advantage.
#Text==Boston Baked Bean Cakes.
#Text==--These are made of left-over baked beans.
#Text=ingredients.
#Text=Flavor to taste.
#Text=Lastly add two well beaten eggs and drop
#Text= from spoon into greased bag or flat tin and place in bag.
#Text=Seal and bake
#Text= in moderate oven about fifteen minutes.
#Text==German Peach Cake.
#Text==--Make a rich baking powder biscuit dough and roll
#Text= out in sheets to fit a long biscuit pan.
#Text=It should not be more than a
#Text= half-inch thick.
#Text=Brush the top with butter and cover with slices of
#Text= peach arranged in symmetrical overlapping rows, or half peaches with the
#Text= rounded side up.
#Text=Sprinkle generously with sugar, cover with another tin
#Text= to prevent the fruit from becoming mushy or hardened, put in bag and
#Text= bake about half an hour in a hot oven.
#Text=This is a good substitute for
#Text= peach pie.
#Text==Pork Cake.
#Text==--This is an old New England dish that has been relegated to
#Text= the background these many years, but is lately coming to the fore.
#Text=A
#Text= gray haired New York physician, dining at my house the other night,
#Text= declared that his old Connecticut aunt  '  s pork cake was one of the
#Text= dearest remembered gustatorial delights of his boyhood.
#Text=To make it chop one pound of fat pork fine.
#Text=Pour over it a pint of
#Text=flour sifted with two teaspoonfuls baking powder.
#Text=Fold in whites of four
#Text= eggs beaten stiff, a cupful of nut meats, preferably English walnuts,
#Text= chopped.
#Text=Bake slowly for about an hour in a gingerbread tin in paper
#Text= bag, making the cake an inch and a half or two inches thick; or else in
#Text= layer tins together with white icing.
#Text=This will make four layers.
#Text==Auburn Pound Cake.
#Text==--Beat to a cream three-fourths pounds of butter and
#Text= one pound fine granulated sugar.
#Text=Add the yolks of nine eggs beaten light
#Text= and one pound flour measured after sifting and then sifted again with a
#Text= teaspoonful and a half of baking powder.
#Text=Fold in the stiffly whipped
#Text= whites and flavor with vanilla, almond or the grated rind and juice of a
#Text= lemon or a wine glass of sherry.
#Text=Pour into well-buttered thin tin mould
#Text= and seal in bags.
#Text=Bake an hour and a quarter or an hour and a half in a
#Text= moderate oven.
#Text==Raisin Nut Cakes.
#Text==--For raisin nut cakes for afternoon tea, beat six
#Text= eggs lightly, beating the whites and with an even teaspoon of soda, one
#Text= teaspoon of sugar creamed with a cupful of butter, a cupful and a half
#Text= of milk and three cupfuls and a half of flour.
#Text=Add a cupful of chopped
#Text= walnuts, two pounds of chopped raisins, a wineglass of brandy, two
#Text=teaspoonfuls of baking powder and spice to taste.
#Text=Make into small cakes,
#Text= put on tin in bag and bake in a moderate oven.
#Text==Sour Cream Cake.
#Text==--Beat together one cup of powdered sugar and one cup
#Text= of sour cream, add two eggs beaten light, one and one-half cups of flour
#Text= sifted twice with an even teaspoon of soda twice, one teaspoon of
#Text= vanilla and one cup of seeded and cut raisins rolled lightly in flour.
#Text=Beat to make the batter creamy and bake at once in a rather shallow pan
#Text= sealed in a paper bag.
#Text=CHAPTER XX.
#Text=FRUITS.
#Text==Baked Apples.
#Text==--WASH, but do not peel; cut out specks and bruises,
#Text= core, fill the bottom of the core-space with a bit of butter, over which
#Text=serving dish, and while still very hot pour over each a dessertspoonful
#Text= of rum.
#Text=Let cool and serve with cake or crisped water biscuit.
#Text==Cinnamon Apples.
#Text==--Peel, core and quarter six good cooking apples,
#Text= preferably greenings.
#Text=Melt a tablespoonful of butter in a warm bowl and
#Text= stir the apples in it until coated with the butter.
#Text=Mix a teaspoonful of
#Text= ground cinnamon with a half cup of granulated sugar, and stir into the
#Text= apples.
#Text=Have a paper bag thoroughly buttered and put the apples in it.
#Text=Rinse out the bowl with a cup of hot water, add it to the apples, seal
#Text= carefully, place on a broiler which rests on a pie plate and bake in a
#Text= hot oven fifteen minutes.
#Text=Half a pint of whipped cream over the apples
#Text= when served is an addition, but they are delicious, cooked in this way,
#Text= without it.
#Text==Apples Stuffed With Figs.
#Text==--Steam tender as many figs as you desire,
#Text= chop into dice and roll each piece in powdered sugar seasoned with
#Text= cinnamon.
#Text=Core large, tart apples and fill the cavities with the figs.
#Text=Bag and bake in a hot oven, adding a little hot water.
#Text=When tender,
#Text= remove carefully to the serving dish and pour over them a syrup made by
#Text= boiling a half cup of sugar with an equal quantity of water.
#Text=Flavor to
#Text=taste and pour over the apples.
#Text=Serve cold with whipped or plain cream.
#Text==Baked Apples and Nuts.
#Text==--For a half dozen large apples a good
#Text= three-fourths cup of nut meats, butternuts, black walnuts or hickory
#Text= nuts--will be required.
#Text=Chop the meats fine and add a half cup of sugar.
#Text=Core the apples and fill the centres with the nuts and sugar.
#Text=Put in a
#Text= rather deep pan, with a cupful of boiling water added, bag and bake.
#Text=When tender remove carefully, place in a pretty dish, pour the juice
#Text= over the apples, and crown with whipped cream or a meringue made from
#Text= the whites of two eggs.
#Text==Raisin Apples.
#Text==--A simple dessert enjoyed by the children consists of
#Text= apples, cored and each cavity filled with sugar, nutmeg, a bit of butter
#Text= and two or three raisins.
#Text=Add one cupful of hot water, put in bag and
#Text= bake in a slow oven.
#Text=This may be varied occasionally by placing a
#Text= meringue on the top of each apple when done, and cooking in a slow oven
#Text= for seven minutes longer.
#Text=Serve cold.
#Text==Baked Apple Sauce.
#Text==--Peel and core firm apples of good flavor.
#Text=Stick
#Text= three cloves in each and put bits of mace and cinnamon in the core
#Text==Baked Peaches.
#Text==--Pour boiling water over the fruit, then rub off the
#Text= skins and place in buttered bag without removing the pits.
#Text=Add a
#Text= teaspoonful of water for each peach, seal and bake about twenty minutes
#Text= in a hot oven.
#Text=When done, sweeten to taste and set aside to chill before
#Text= using.
#Text=Serve with sweet cream.
#Text==Baked Pears.
#Text==--Select ripe, fine-flavored fruit, snip out the blossom
#Text= end and stick in a clove.
#Text=If the skin is thin, do not peel, but if
#Text= tough, remove, put in buttered bag with a little water, seal and cook
#Text= from fifteen to thirty minutes according to the quality of the fruit.
#Text==Baked Plums.
#Text==--Put in buttered bag with a little water and cook twenty
#Text= or twenty-five minutes.
#Text=Sweeten to taste when done.
#Text==Baked Quinces.
#Text==--Wash, core and peel, fill the centers with sugar and
#Text= put in greased bag with two tablespoonfuls of water allowed for each
#Text= quince.
#Text=Seal and bake slowly for an hour, until the quince is tender but
#Text= not mushy.
#Text=Serve with the quince syrup and a spoonful of whipped cream
#Text= on top of each quince.
#Text==Baked Raisins.
#Text==--Remove stems, clean well, put in a colander and wash
#Text= thoroughly.
#Text=Put in buttered bag with a cupful of water for each cupful
#Text= of raisins.
#Text=Seal and cook slowly for half an hour.
#Text=A mixture of dried
#Text= apricots, prunes and cherries is nice with the raisins, but these fruits
#Text= need long soaking in cold water before adding to the raisins and
#Text= cooking.
#Text==Chestnut Patties.
#Text==--Beat together, until smooth, one egg and one cupful
#Text= of pulverized sugar.
#Text=Add one cupful of chestnut meats that have been put
#Text= through a nut grinder, five tablespoonfuls of flour and one teaspoonful
#Text= of baking powder.
#Text=Beat lightly, then drop by spoonfuls on buttered tins.
#Text=Dust with pulverized sugar and cinnamon.
#Text=Put in bag and bake in a quick
#Text= oven.
#Text=CHAPTER XXI.
#Text=PASTRY.
#Text=USE tin or agate pie plates for paper bag cookery.
#Text=Line with a delicate
#Text= crust, and prick the bottom with a fork.
#Text=Turn in whatever filling you
#Text= elect to have, and put on top crust or the latticed bars.
#Text=Cut a cross in
#Text= the center of a solid crust and turn back the points or prick with a
#Text= fork.
#Text=Any pie can be baked in a paper bag with advantage.
#Text=Cook two pies
#Text= at once, shifting midway in the cooking from the upper to the lower
#Text= shelves and vice versa.
#Text=Have the oven hot when the pies go in, but
#Text= reduce the heat as soon as the bag corners turn brown.
#Text=Average pies
#Text= require about half an hour for the baking.
#Text==Plain Pie Crust.
#Text==--For each pie allow a heaping cupful of pastry flour
#Text= and sift into a cold bowl with a half teaspoonful of salt and a
#Text= saltspoonful of baking powder.
#Text=Have ready a quarter cupful of butter
#Text= that has been washed in cold water, then chilled on the ice.
#Text=Work into
#Text= the sifted flour a quarter cupful of lard or vegetable shortening, using
#Text= the tips of the fingers or a case knife.
#Text=As soon as the flour begins to
#Text= feel like coarse meal, moisten to a dough with cold water.
#Text=Add a little
#Text= at a time, handling the crust as lightly as possible.
#Text=It will take about
#Text=superior richness.
#Text=For its baking a pudding dish at least three and a
#Text= half inches deep is chosen.
#Text=This is lined with a rich crust, a square
#Text= of the dough being taken from the bottom.
#Text=Now peel enough ripe and
#Text= luscious peaches to fill the dish, tearing them apart but leaving the
#Text= pits in to impart their superior flavor.
#Text=Sweeten abundantly, add about
#Text= two tablespoonfuls water, and a tablespoonful of butter cut in bits.
#Text=Cover with a layer of puff paste, sealing it down carefully on the sides
#Text= to the border, so as to lose none of the juices.
#Text=Bag and bake in a quick
#Text= oven for forty-five minutes.
#Text=When nearly done, draw to the edge of the
#Text= oven, open the top of the bag, dust with powdered sugar and set back a
#Text= few moments longer for the crust to glaze.
#Text=This is perfection, whether
#Text= eaten hot or cold, serving it alone, with cream or with a hard sauce as
#Text= preferred.
#Text==Peach Roly Poly.
#Text==--Make a sweet biscuit dough.
#Text=Roll out thin and spread
#Text= with a layer of sliced or chopped peaches and roll the dough over as for
#Text= jelly roll.
#Text=Put in buttered bag and bake in a moderate oven.
#Text==Plum Roly Poly.
#Text==--Wash and stew any ripe sound plums and remove the
#Text= pits.
#Text=If very juicy, drain away the most of the juice.
#Text=Sweeten to taste.
#Text=Make a good biscuit dough or puff paste as preferred, roll out in long
#Text= strips, sprinkle sugar on the upper side, then spread thinly with the
#Text= stewed plums, roll up and pinch the ends tight.
#Text=Put in buttered bag and
#Text= cook thirty minutes.
#Text=Serve with a sauce made from the extra juice
#Text= sweetened and slightly thickened with a little cornstarch.
#Text==Rye Bread Pudding.
#Text==--Toast stale rye bread to a golden brown, then roll
#Text= into fine crumbs.
#Text=Brush small custard cups or a mould with melted
#Text= butter, sprinkle over a few currants, raisins, prunes (cut fine) or
#Text= figs, then fill with crumbs.
#Text=Beat three eggs without separating until
#Text= light, add three tablespoonfuls of sugar, a pint of milk (with vanilla
#Text= or nutmeg to flavor) and pour carefully over the bread crumbs.
#Text=Let them
#Text= stand ten minutes, until the mixture has soaked into the crumbs; then
#Text= set in a paper bag in a pan of cold water and cook like a custard in the
#Text= oven.
#Text=It will take about half an hour.
#Text=Test by slipping the blade of the
#Text= knife down the side of the bag.
#Text=If it comes up clear, the pudding is
#Text= sufficiently baked.
#Text=Serve hot with lemon or egg sauce or fruit syrup.
#Text==Tapioca Apple Pudding.
#Text==--Soak one cupful tapioca in three pints cold
#Text= water over night.
#Text=In the morning put on to boil and cook twenty or
#Text=thirty minutes, until it looks clear.
#Text=Add a quart and a half peeled and
#Text= quartered apples, one cup of sugar, a teaspoonful salt, and lemon juice
#Text= or extract to flavor.
#Text=Turn into a buttered dish, put in bag and bake an
#Text= hour in a moderate oven.
#Text=When cold serve with cream and sugar.
#Text==A White Plum Pudding.
#Text==--Beat to a cream a half cup of sugar and
#Text= three-quarters cup of butter.
#Text=Add four eggs well beaten, a saltspoonful
#Text= of salt, two cups milk, a quart of flour mixed with one-half cup
#Text= shredded citron, one-half cup currants, a teaspoonful grated nutmeg and
#Text= a teaspoonful vanilla.
#Text=Just before turning into the mould stir in two
#Text= even tablespoonfuls pure baking powder.
#Text=Put in bag, surround with water,
#Text= steam two hours and serve with any good sauce.
#Text=PUDDING SAUCES.
#Text==Caramel Sauce.
#Text==--Put one-half cupful of sugar over the fire in a clean,
#Text= smooth saucepan and stir until it becomes a light brown color.
#Text=Pour in
#Text= a half cupful of boiling water, simmer ten minutes, add a tablespoonful
#Text=of butter and serve with pudding or fritters.
#Text==Cornstarch Pudding Sauce.
#Text==--Beat together one tablespoonful cornstarch,
#Text= two tablespoonfuls of butter and a half cupful of brown sugar.
#Text=Set on
#Text= the stove until heated, then turn in hot water a little at a time and
#Text= cook until consistency required.
#Text=Add four tablespoonfuls of grape or
#Text= apple jelly with spices or other flavoring to taste, and serve hot.
#Text==Cream Sauce.
#Text==--Mix together two tablespoonfuls each of cornstarch and
#Text= sugar.
#Text=Add one beaten egg and cook in double boiler until thickened.
#Text=Add
#Text= a tablespoonful of butter and flavoring to taste.
#Text==Cream Sauce à la Hotel Astor.
#Text==--Beat together one cupful each sugar and
#Text= butter until perfectly blended.
#Text=Add cream until mixture is like thick
#Text= cream, dust with nutmeg or mace and serve.
#Text==Delicious Fruit Sauce for Plum Pudding.
#Text==--Boil together one cupful of
#Text= water and two of sugar for ten minutes.
#Text=Thicken slightly with three
#Text= level teaspoonfuls arrow root or two teaspoonfuls corn starch mixed with
#Text= a little cold water, simmer five minutes, then add a half cupful candied
#Text=cherries, cut in halves and a few pistache nuts quartered.
#Text=Flavor with
#Text= nutmeg or vanilla as preferred.
#Text==Hard Sauce for Plum Pudding.
#Text==--Beat one cupful of butter to a cream.
#Text=Add sugar gradually, two cupfuls in all, beating until very light.
#Text=Add
#Text= the whites of two eggs beaten to a stiff dry foam.
#Text=Arrange on a flat
#Text= glass dish and grate a little nutmeg over it.
#Text==Molasses Sauce.
#Text==--To make molasses sauce, which is an excellent
#Text= accompaniment to a plain rice or apple pudding, mix together one cupful
#Text= of molasses, a tablespoonful of vinegar or the juice of one lemon, a
#Text= saltspoonful of salt and a tablespoonful of butter.
#Text=Boil ten minutes.

#Text=

#Text=With our Cookery Dishes you can give to all meats the delicious taste
#Text= which has heretofore been secured only by planking steaks and fish.
#Text=The sweet wood--we use sugar-maple only--is always fresh, giving an
#Text= effect that cannot be maintained permanently by the ordinary plank.
#Text=Everything that can be cooked in a paper bag tastes better if you use
